docket_entries.description: ORDER granting  19  25   Motion to Dismiss.  The case is therefore DISMISSED  for failure to state a claim under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6).  Because the Complaint has already been amended once and further amendment  would be futile, the dismissal is with prejudice,  by Judge Marsha J. Pechman.(MD)

case_data.name: Mahoney v. Holder
case_data.plaintiff_description: Approximately 125 named police officers from the Seattle Police Department

related_cases.name: United States v. City of Seattle

case_data.summary:
On May 28, 2014, approximately 125 police officers from the Seattle Police Department (SPD) brought this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington. The case was assigned to Judge Marsha J. Pechman. The plaintiffs each individually sued the U.S. Department of Justice and the City of Seattle, including the SPD and the Seattle Police Monitor Team, under 42 U.S.C. ยง1983 for their roles in implementing Seattleโs new use of force policy (UF policy). The new UF policy limited police officersโ ability to use force against civilians without repercussions, and the plaintiffs argued that this policy violated their constitutional rights under the Second, Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments. Specifically, they alleged that the policy violated their constitutional right to self-defense, as well as Due Process and Equal Protection. Initially representing themselves pro se, the plaintiffs sought declaratory relief, injunctive relief, damages, and attorneysโ fees and costs.

On August 21, 2014, the City of Seattle moved to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a claim. It alleged that the plaintiffs had misunderstood both what their constitutional rights were and what the new UF policy did, as the officersโ claims were not supported by the U.S. Constitution or by case law. On the same day, the Seattle Police Monitor Team filed a motion to dismiss the case because the members of the monitor team had quasi-judicial immunity. The monitors were appointed by the court as part of a consent decree from an earlier settlement in United States v. City of Seattle regarding the SPDโs excessive use of force. So, the monitors argued, they could not be considered part of the city the way that the SPD could.

Six days after the motions were filed, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint that added new factual allegations about the policy and removed those plaintiffs that no longer wished to litigate. The amended complaint emphasized the idea of constitutional self-defense as a right embedded in several amendments rather than stated outright. In September 2014, the defendants filed two motions to dismiss offering arguments similar to those found in the motions to dismiss the original complaint. On October 9, the court held oral arguments on the issue. The plaintiffs also obtained private counsel during this month.

On October 17, 2014, the court granted both motions to dismiss. Because the complaint had already been amended once and amending it further would be โfutile,โ Judge Pechman dismissed the case with prejudice. 62 F.Supp.3d 1215. The court held that the monitor team had quasi-judicial immunity and, even without it, the plaintiffsโ claims betrayed their misunderstanding regarding what their constitutional rights were, and the constitutional right to self-defense did not exist; the plaintiffs had failed to allege that any of the defendants had violated their rights.

On November 14, 2014, the plaintiffs appealed the case to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The Ninth Circuit affirmed the lower courtโs decision nearly three years later, on September 19, 2017, finding that neither the case law nor the constitution entitled the plaintiffs to self-defense. 871 F.3d 873.

On December 28, 2017, the plaintiffs petitioned the U.S. Supreme Court to hear this case. On April 2, 2018, their petition was denied. The plaintiffs exhausted their options for appealing this case, and it is now closed.
case_data.summary_short: In May 2014, approximately 125 police officers from the Seattle Police Department (SPD) brought this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington. The plaintiffs alleged that SPD's new policy that limited the amount of force they could use on civilians was a violation of their constitutional right to self-defense. The court dismissed the case in October 2017, holding that there was no constitutional right to self-defense. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed the holding.

II. BACKGROUND AND FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS, INCLUDING SPECIFIC PROVISIONS OF 
1  THE NEW UF POLICY THAT BURDEN PLAINTIFFS' RIGHT OF SELF-DEFENSE 
 
2  8.  On December 17, 2013, Judge Robart, United States District Court Judge for the 
Western District of Washington at Seattle, issued an order approving an alleged 
3 
"Consensus Use of Force Policy" (UF Policy) to govern SPD.  Judge Robart approved 
4 
the policy as appropriate โfor the present circumstances." It went into effect on 
5 
January 1, 2014.  Officers were required to have read the new policy by that date, 
6 
and officers' conduct has been evaluated under the policy since that date. 
7 
9.  The "circumstances" referred to by Judge Robart include an investigation opened in 
8 
March, 2011 by DOJ regarding whether or not SPD officers deprived individuals of 
9  their constitutional rights by patterns and practices of discriminatory policing or 
10  excessive use of force.  After its investigation, DOJ was unable to make any 
findings of discriminatory policing.  However, DOJ did issue 'findings' including 
11 
that SPD patrol officers use force "in an unconstitutional manner nearly 20% of the 
12 
time." The City "dispute[d] the alleged patterns or practices of excessive force 
13 
alleged in DOJ's report,"  and the findings were discredited by an independent 
14

15 
10. Nevertheless, Judge Robart approved the UF Policy as "the most appropriate remedy,"

18  specific policies" were thus needed.  This contradicts long-standing Supreme Court 
19  holdings that consistently acknowledge but reject concerns about 'vagueness' and 
'troubling uncertainty,' holding that simplicity, flexibility, and deference to the 
20 
officer, instead, are essential for standards governing lawful police action, 
21 
especially regarding search and seizure, including force. 
22 
11. Judge Robart indicated that his role was to "insure" that the UF Policy was 
23 
constitutional.  However, his cursory, one-and-one-half-page order contains no 
24

25 
relates to Plaintiffs' constitutional right to protect and defend the public and 
26  themselves from threatening and dangerous behavior by suspects.   
27  12.  In July 2012, a Settlement Agreement and Memorandum of Understanding (Consent 
28  Agreement) was entered into between the United States and the City.  The City 
 
3

The Honorable Marsha J. Pechman 
agreed to develop a new UF policy consistent with the constitutional requirements 
1 
of Graham v. Connor.   The stated goal of the parties was to create polices that 
2 
are constitutional and that "ensure public and officer safety."  The City was 
3 
supposed to retain appropriate "flexibility" and have the "ability to develop local 
4  and cost effective solutions."   
5  13. The Consent Agreement also provided that the parties would select a federal monitor 
6  to oversee implementation of the Consent Agreement.  Defendant Merrick Bobb 
(Monitor) is that monitor.  To date, based on bills reported publicly, the City has

work regarding the Consent Decree on a website called the "Website of the Seattle

Police Monitor" (seattlemonitor.com).  The Monitor maintains another website,

โPolice Assessment Resource Centerโ (www.parc.info), that promotes the full range

of services Mr. Bobb will provide for a fee to promote and induce civilian 
12

13  organization has a zealous agenda to spread the message of police reform and to 
14  steer police departments into adopting similarly written, highly proscriptive UF

16

discretion and use force. 
18

with an accompanying Memorandum to the Court (UF Memorandum).  The Monitor concedes

that it is not his role to write the new UF Policy and states unconvincingly that

regarding the UF situations facing patrol officers in Seattle.  Moreover, many SPD

The Honorable Marsha J. Pechman 
and standards.  However, no SPD officers concurrently engaged in street policing 
1 
duties or related training were involved in the development of the UF Policy.

19.  To say, as the Monitor does repeatedly, that the Policy represents the "consensus"

and "unified" voice of the parties is inaccurate to the point of falsification.  As

23  21. The falsity as to the City's and SPD's alleged agreement with the new UF Policy has

24

25 
that they agree with the allegations in the original complaint.  Nevertheless, 
26

27

28 
significant changes to the policy, even during the current "review" of the policy 
 
6 

Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 13   Filed 08/27/14   Page 7 of 34
The Honorable Marsha J. Pechman 
built into the Consent Decree.  This means that the City is now knowingly and 
1 
willingly playing politics with Plaintiffs' lives and the lives of the law-abiding 
2 
citizens of Seattle. 
3 
22. There is increasing evidence of significant problems wrought by the new UF Policy.  
4  Plaintiffs allege that since they filed their original complaint, assaults against 
5  SPD officers have increased significantly.  Evidence of police injuries is 
6  mounting.  Officers are turning in their TASERS in large numbers - even though such 
devices provide reasonable and effective tools when facing threatening behavior and 
7 
activity.  Patrols officers will testify to an insidious new hesitation to respond 
8 
to calls for backup.  First-responding officers, required by the UF Policy to delay 
9 
and avoid resorting to force, are left unreasonably vulnerable when backup fails to 
10 
come, or comes late, and these delay and avoidance tactics fail to bring the threat 
11 
under control in a timely and decisive manner.   
12 
23. Even as Plaintiffs were filing the original complaint asserting the significant 
13  risks to public safety created by the new UF Policy, SPD itself was issuing a 
14  report regarding the sharp decrease in proactive police work to investigate and 
15  stop crime.  Citizens are feeling vulnerable as the City's streets seem ever more 
at the mercy of hostile and unstable persons. Patrol officers have retreated from 
16 
and avoided acting in response to clear threats to their own safety and that of the 
17 
public for fear of accusations of violating some provision of the UF Policy or new 
18 
expectations and practices regarding force.  Not surprisingly, innocent bystanders 
19 
have expressed anger and concern at what they see as officers' failure to protect 
20 
innocent people.  Citizens groups are demanding more enforcement resources to deal 
21 
with increasingly violent incidents throughout the City. This increased lawlessness 
22  and disregard of police authority are the logical and inevitable consequences of a 
23  policy that puts the interests of criminal suspects above the rights and interests 
of citizens, officers, and the City itself. 
24 
24. Patrol officers are currently being subject to discipline under the new UF 
25 
Policy both for using too much force and for using too little force, thus 
26 
supporting Plaintiffs' allegation that the new policy demands 'perfection', 
27 
not reasonableness.  This trend towards a misguided and impossible standard 
28 
of policing began with former Mayor McGinn's politically motivated promise, 
 
7 

Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 13   Filed 08/27/14   Page 8 of 34
The Honorable Marsha J. Pechman 
to appease DOJ, that police officers using force "will get it right every 
1 
time." This trend has now become enshrined in the Department's new policies 
2 
and practices, as well as the attitudes of those sitting in judgment of 
3 
officers after the fact. Plaintiffs have taken the opportunity to observe 
4  meetings of the Use of Force Review Board (UFRB), which, under the new 
5  policy, is required for every so-called Type II and III UF incident. In 
6  specific cases, patrol officers and detectives have been criticized and/or 
recommended for disciplinary investigation, despite having had practical 
7 
safety reasons for their conduct due to the dynamic and dangerous nature of 
8 
the situation and the threat created by the suspect.  The Monitor, who was 
9 
in attendance at a meeting attended by Plaintiffs, emphatically stated in 
10 
response to one of these cases: "Practical considerations never trump this 
11 
policy."   This is a 180-degree contortion of officers' right to self-
12 
defense and the Court's holdings that prioritize officer and public safety 
13  over the mechanical application of legal standards and policies.  
14  25. Plaintiffs will testify to being significantly less sure of how to police 
15  under the new UF Policy than even when they first became police officers.  
Officers will testify that the training received under the new UF Policy has 
16 
done nothing to make sense of the UF Policy's confusion and complications.  
17 
This is not surprising as officers cannot be trained to meet an impossible 
18 
standard.  None of the training addresses the crucial situation that has 
19 
officers scratching their heads and fearing for their lives and the lives of 
20 
others, including suspects: what, if any, actions can officers realistically 
21 
take when confronted with threatening behavior by one of the protected 
22  classes of people for whom the policy prohibits any reasonable force tools 
23  short of deadly force?  Moreover, the training materials recommended for 
approval by the Monitor regarding suspects in behavioral crisis simply 
24 
entrench the existing problems with the UF Policy itself, demanding police 
25 
officers, in effect, become mental health professionals at the expense of 
26 
their duty and safety.  Plaintiffs' role is, and should be, to assess the 
27 
threat and take reasonable actions to protect the public and themselves from 
28 
the risk of harm.  It cannot be stated too strongly that a threat of danger 
 
8 

Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 13   Filed 08/27/14   Page 9 of 34
The Honorable Marsha J. Pechman 
is a threat of danger, regardless of the suspect's mental health or other 
1 
impairments that may be contributing factors to the suspect's criminal 
2 
behavior! 
3 
26. All parties agree that SPD's UF incidents often involve people with mental 
4  illness and/or under the influence of drugs or alcohol.  DOJ and the Monitor 
5  seem to believe this makes all of SPD's uses of force automatically suspect.  
6  At the same time, however, DOJ concedes in its findings letters that police 
officers have become the first responders in a shameful national crisis.  
7 
DOJ recognizes there is neither the will nor the resources to provide 
8 
appropriate treatment to the mentally ill.  DOJ acknowledges the rotating 
9 
door through hospitals and jails that quickly and inevitably puts the 
10 
mentally ill worse off, and often on the street where there is ready access 
11 
to drugs, alcohol, and dangerous weapons, and where victims can quickly 
12 
become suspects engaged in activity that threatens the public's safety.  The 
13  dangerous, unpredictable, often violent, behavior that results is well 
14  documented.  Indeed, police officers, like the public they serve, are 
15  regularly reminded of the deadly outcomes by a steady stream of horrifying 
news stories of mentally ill people murdering people, often in large 
16 
numbers, here and across the country.  The difference is that officers are 
17 
on the front line of a ticking time bomb. Policy and training that require 
18 
delay and hesitation are not preparing officers to act decisively when, as 
19 
will be inevitable, they find themselves quickly and unexpectedly with their 
20 
lives on the line.   
21  27. Since Plaintiffs have filed this lawsuit, they have been accused of being 
22  "fringe" or "rouge" cops and dismissed as reflexively 'anti-reform.โ  
23  Plaintiffs, however, represent a significant percentage of patrol officers, 
whose job is to patrol the street, as well as a large number of training 
24 
personnel who take seriously their duty to help patrol officers come home 
25 
safely from each shift.  Plaintiffs have consistently supported appropriate 
26 
reform, e.g. civilian oversight of the department by the Office of 
27 
Professional Accountability. Plaintiffs do not oppose reform related to UF, 
28 
 
9 

Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 13   Filed 08/27/14   Page 10 of 34
The Honorable Marsha J. Pechman 
but are asking that reform be consistent with officers' constitutional 
1 
rights as well as those of suspects.  
2 
28. There are many extremely troubling aspects of DOJ's investigation that 
3 
Plaintiffs do not challenge, because it is not their role or their rights 
4  are not immediately at stake.  These problems include DOJ's complete 
5  overriding of local decision-making, the Monitor's use of the Consent Decree 
6  to infiltrate and control almost every aspect of SPD, and the debilitating 
strain on enforcement resources wrought by the new prioritization of UF 
7 
reporting and investigation paperwork requirements over the need to respond 
8 
to actual crime.  Plaintiffs challenge the latter only to the extent that 
9 
the strain puts officers' and citizens' lives in danger by pulling an 
10 
inordinate number of officers off the street for long periods of time even 
11 
for relatively minor UF incidents. 
12 
29. This is the crux and basis of all Plaintiffs' allegations.  Policy cannot 
13  stand that restricts and burdens officers' right to defend themselves and 
14  others from threats of serious harm. So-called, best practices that violate 
15  the fundamental, individual rights of police officers have no place in the 
law enforcement profession.  Mr. Bobb and his organization PARC have long 
16 
been attempting to sell the notion that police departments are completely 
17 
free to adopt policies and practices that are more restrictive than the law.  
18 
Plaintiffs, however, contend that this freedom is not absolute. Rather, it 
19 
is limited to the point at which it begins to tread upon the fundamental, 
20 
individual constitutional rights of the officers subject to such a policy. 
21 
Plaintiffs assert that, although police officers are public servants, they 
22  are not enslaved to the government or public. Therefore, despite being 
23  representatives of the government and subject to reasonable policy 
requirements and expectations, police officers also possess the same 
24

III.  CONSTITUTIONAL CLAIMS 
3 
A.  By Promulgating and Implementing the UF Policy, Defendants have 
violated Plaintiffs' Constitutional Right of Self-Defense. 
4   
63.  When a police officer is confronted with threatening behavior, he or she 
5 
has the right to take reasonable actions in defense of self and others.  
6 
Plaintiffs' right of self-defense is 'fundamental,' 'basic,' 'natural,' 
7 
'central,' and 'inherent.'  For well over a century, the Court has held that 
8 
the right of self-defense existed prior to, and did not depend upon being 
9  granted by, the Constitution.  It is an individual right of "universal 
10  application" that is in no way diminished because Plaintiffs have chosen to 
be police officers.  The right to use force in self-defense is an immediate 
11 
right based on the immediacy of the threat or danger.  The right recognizes 
12 
a continuity of action such that officers can employ any and all reasonable 
13 
means until the perceived threat has been fully extinguished. An essential 
14 
attribute of this right is that it does not turn on the facts and 
15 
circumstances determined afterwards, but instead on whether or not there 
16 
were reasonable grounds for a person's belief that he or she was in imminent 
17  or immediate danger at the moment of the incident.  Detached reflection 
18  cannot be demanded in the presence of an immediate threat of serious 
19  physical harm.  The above allegations provide multiple examples of the 
specific ways the UF Policy violates these long-standing standards that 
20 
ensure the individual's right of self-defense. The UF Policy then not only 
21 
invites but demands unconstitutional second-guessing of UF decisions. 
22 
B.  By Promulgating and Implementing the UF Policy, Defendants have 
23  violated the Second Amendment. 
 
64. The fundamental right to self-defense "pre-exists" and is broader than the 
24 
specific Second Amendment right to keep and bear arms, although it is 
25 
embodied in and is the central component of this right. Therefore, 
26 
Defendants actions in unreasonably restricting and burdening Plaintiffs 
27 
right of self-defense violate the Second Amendment.  Moreover, the contours 
28 
of Plaintiffs' Second Amendment rights shape an appropriate understanding of 
 
22 

Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 13   Filed 08/27/14   Page 23 of 34
The Honorable Marsha J. Pechman 
their broader constitutional right to self-defense.  The right to keep and 
1 
bear arms is a right that is exercised individually and belongs to each and 
2 
every American citizen, regardless of profession, and is not limited to use 
3 
of an officer's firearm.  The right has been understood not merely as the 
4  right to use force after a confrontation has occurred but includes the right 
5  to be prepared or ready in case of the possibility of a conflict or 
6  confrontation with an assailant.  Plaintiffs recognize that these rights are 
not unlimited and can be subject to legitimate and appropriate regulation.  
7 
Nevertheless, the specific right to keep and bear arms is an 'enshrinement' 
8 
of a fundamental right to self-defense, which means that regulations cannot 
9 
burden such rights to the point of destruction, or render them practically 
10 
meaningless.  As the above allegations make clear, decision-making under the 
11 
UF Policy is sufficiently proscribed so that police officers cannot act 
12 
decisively in the moment, based on an assessment of the threat, to bring 
13  situations under control in order to protect themselves and others from 
14  harm.  
15  65. Plaintiffs know their job puts them in danger.  They accept these risks in 
large part because their job also allows them the privilege to serve and 
16 
protect the innocent.  Plaintiffs are not arguing that the Constitution 
17 
grants them the right to dictate all the terms of a UF Policy or requires 
18 
the City to keep them safe at all times.  The Constitution, however, 
19 
provides Plaintiffs the fundamental right of self-defense.  The City cannot 
20 
make policy decisions and impose policy requirements that consistently and 
21 
inevitably place them at unnecessary and, therefore, unreasonable risk when 
22  confronting dangerous suspects.  Such policy choices have been taken off the 
23  table by the law. 
C.  By Promulgating and Implementing the UF Policy, Defendants have 
24 
violated the Fourth Amendment. 
 
25 
66. The Supreme Court's Fourth Amendment jurisprudence is the core guide 
26  regarding police interactions with persons engaged, or suspected of 
27  engagement, in criminal activity.  It contains clear and long-standing 
28  standards and principles regarding seizures.  Plaintiffs argue that when 
 
23 

Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 13   Filed 08/27/14   Page 24 of 34
The Honorable Marsha J. Pechman 
they are unnecessarily required to face death or serious injury in such 
1 
encounters, because of the policies of their employer, they have been 
2 
intentionally and unreasonably seized in violation of their Fourth Amendment 
3 
rights.  A policy with these identified dangers does not simply create the 
4  random chance of harm to the officer, it makes it a virtual certainty due to 
5  the nature of the job itself and the fact that the government requires them 
6  to perform it under the flawed UF Policy each and every day. 
D. By Promulgating and Implementing the UF Policy, Defendants have 
7 
violated the Plaintiffs' Right of Self-Defense as Embedded in the Fourth 
Amendment. 
8 
 
67. Without finding a specific Fourth Amendment seizure of officers harmed because of 
9 
the UF Policy, long-standing Fourth Amendment case law still embeds and recognizes 
10 
a police officer's fundamental right of self-defense.  Even as it balances 
11 
governments' versus citizens' interests, the Court finds a separate, more 
12 
fundamental and pre-existing right at play, viz. officers' right to take necessary 
13  and reasonable steps to secure their own safety and that of bystanders when 
14  conducting a seizure: in short, defense of self and others.  For "certainly it 
15  would be unreasonable to require that police officers take unnecessary risks in the 
performance of their duties." The Court has made clear that officers do not have to 
16 
first take a chance on arguably less intrusive measures and 'hope for the best.'  
17 
As the Fourth Circuit put it succinctly, "The Constitution simply does not require 
18 
police to gamble with their lives in the face of a serious threat of harm." This is 
19 
not a hollow right to recover damages (or for officers' widows and children to 
20 
recover such) after they have been seriously or fatally injured.  The 
21 
constitutional injury occurs regardless of whether or not a police officer happens 
22  to be lucky enough to avoid, or to protect himself or herself from, actual harm in 
23  the face of danger.  Instead, the right of self-defense by necessity means that the 
City cannot unreasonably restrict or burden the timing and/or range of reasonable 
24 
options officers may employ in protecting themselves and others.  "It would be 
25 
clearly unreasonable to deny the officer the power to take necessary measures in 
26 
order to neutralize the threat of physical harm." 
27 
68. In determining whether or not there was unnecessary and therefore unreasonable risk 
28 
to the officer's safety, the Court examines whether or not the officer was 
 
24 

Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 13   Filed 08/27/14   Page 25 of 34
The Honorable Marsha J. Pechman 
'justified,' in other words, reasonable, in his or her belief regarding the present 
1 
threat of danger.  This is also the single most important factor in the objective 
2 
reasonableness standard under the Fourth Amendment.  Thus, the totality of the 
3 
circumstances standard teaches us about officers' right of self-defense. The Court 
4  has been careful not to permit Fourth Amendment standards that invite recklessness 
5  or create perverse incentives for criminal suspects to disregard public safety any 
6  further than they already do.  The Court requires that every police encounter, from 
social contact through the use of deadly force, be judged by one, consistent, long-
7 
standing standard: reasonableness. There is no 'magic on/off switch' or 'rigid 
8 
preconditions' for when, or what type of, force is appropriate in a particular 
9 
case.  "All that matters is whether the officer's actions were reasonable."  For 
10 
the same reason, the Court rejects application of separate tracks or categorical 
11 
rules when evaluating an officerโs conduct in relation to a mentally ill suspect, 
12 
or one of any other category.  Even as courts, including the Ninth Circuit, 
13  complain of its "troubling degree of uncertainty," the Court consistently rejects 
14  attempts at producing a neat set of rules.  Instead, the actual, cumulative 
15  information available to the officer on the scene, combined with his own experience 
and specialized training, always trumps pre-set rules, categorical schemes, or use 
16 
of post-hoc 'divide and conquerโ analysis of the officer's decision.  As the above 
17 
allegations demonstrate, the UF Policy, throughout, contradicts these standards of 
18 
reasonableness, flexibility and deference, instead restricting and burdening 
19 
Plaintiffs' right of self-defense.   
20 
E.  By Promulgating and Implementing the UF Policy, Defendants have violated 
the Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments. 
21 
 
69. The UF Policy rewards suspects' recklessness and disregard for the safety of others 
22 
as it consistently disadvantages officers in the face of volatile, unpredictable, 
23 
threatening behavior by suspects.  The UF Policy thus places Plaintiffs at 
24 
considerable disadvantage compared to suspects and the general public as regards 
25 
their fundamental right to defend themselves from threats of deadly harm and 
26  serious bodily injury.  This denies Plaintiffs the equal protection of the law as 
27  prohibited by the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments.  Moreover, Plaintiffs have 
28  asserted a fundamental constitutional right of self-defense and Defendants have not 
 
25 

Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 13   Filed 08/27/14   Page 26 of 34
The Honorable Marsha J. Pechman 
asserted a justification sufficient to satisfy the heightened scrutiny required by 
1 
equal protection law. 
2 
F.  By Promulgating and Implementing the UF Policy, Defendants have violated 
Plaintiffs' Substantive and Procedural Due Process under the Fifth and 
3 
Fourteenth Amendments. 
 
4  70. The Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment prohibits a federal agency, such as 
5  DOJ, from depriving individuals of life, liberty, or property without the due 
6  process of law.  Similarly, the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment 
prohibits state actors from doing the same.  Clearly such rights are at stake here.  
7 
Plaintiffs allege that the UF Policy subjects them to unnecessary risk of death and 
8 
serious bodily injury.  Plaintiffs believe we will face unreasonable disciplinary 
9 
actions, lawsuits, loss of employment, and the inability to obtain police 
10 
employment in other jurisdictions if and when we are accused of violating the new 
11 
UF Policy, even though our actions were reasonable under the law.   
12 
71. Substantive due process claims have been brought by suspects alleging excessive use 
13  of force by the government in cases where the suspect cannot establish that there 
14  has been an intentional seizure by the government.   These cases, though brought by 
15  suspects, reflect the underlying, embedded right of self-defense of the police 
officer involved and, thus, shed light on the contours of Plaintiffs' right of 
16 
self-defense.   Thus, for example, rules of due process, like the reasonableness 
17 
standard, cannot be subject to mechanical application and must take into account 
18 
that officers often will not have the luxury to make unhurried judgments.  
19 
Moreover, evaluation of officer conduct must consider that officers often need to 
20 
act quickly even as decision-making is complicated by pulls of competing 
21 
obligations, i.e. the need to act decisively and to show restraint at the same 
22  moment.  All of these realities are relevant to evaluating an officer's conduct 
23  when his or her actions are taken in response to suspect's threatening behavior.  
None of these realities are reflected in the UF Policy.   
24 
72. Due process however is not only for the benefit of suspects.  Plaintiffs assert a 
25 
substantive due process violation of our own liberty and property interests.  
26 
Regardless of whether or not Plaintiffs can establish that the policy's 
27 
restrictions and burdens are a seizure under the Fourth Amendment, DOJ's and the 
28 
City's deliberate indifference to long-standing rights of self-defense, as they 
 
26 

Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 13   Filed 08/27/14   Page 27 of 34
The Honorable Marsha J. Pechman 
force Plaintiffs to conform to a policy that blatantly violates those rights, is an 
1 
abuse of power that shocks the conscience.  Defendants know that the policy is 
2 
fundamentally flawed and puts public safety and officers' lives in jeopardy, yet 
3 
they still refuse to change it because it would be 'too hard' politically.   Other 
4  Defendants show callous and aggressive disregard when confronted with evidence of 
5  the threat to public and officer safety created by the UF Policy.   It is 
6  unconscionable and an abuse of authority when, in light of such evidence, those in 
power are permitted to equate public safety concerns with buying "Cheerios" in a 
7 
"grocery store."  
8 
73. DOJ has imposed, and the City and SPD have acquiesced in, a fundamental rewriting 
9 
of nearly universal, long-standing, constitutionally-grounded rules of reasonable 
10 
police conduct based on a secretive and fundamentally flawed factual analysis.  
11 
This violates both substantive and procedural due process. DOJ repeatedly refused 
12 
to provide the City, SPD or the public with the data, methods, or analysis it used 
13  to reach its conclusions.  The little information DOJ did provide indicates that 
14  its key finding comes from an extrapolation from a random sample of UF reports.  It 
15  is therefore nothing more than speculation.  An independent and complete analysis 
by researchers under the supervision of Matthew Hickman, a Professor at Seattle 
16 
University, and a former statistician for DOJ itself found that only 3.5% of cases 
17 
could be characterized as even "potentially" excessive.  In addition, DOJ's finding 
18 
regarding the prevalence of excessive force directly conflicts with other key 
19 
findings by DOJ, such as, the โgreat majorityโ of Seattleโs police officers do not 
20 
use excessive force; the pattern of excessive force exists only for a very small 
21 
โsubsetโ of officers; and that supervisory oversight should focus only on the โvery 
22  small numberโ of officers who use force frequently. 
23  74. Defendants have imposed the new UF Policy without providing Plaintiffs any 
meaningful opportunity to be heard, even though it is their safety and livelihood 
24 
that is most significantly and immediately affected by the policy changes.  They 
25 
did so without meaningful consultation with or involvement from SPOG.  They did so 
26 
notwithstanding that many SPD patrol officers are recognized experts in the field 
27 
of use of force standards and techniques. They ignored Plaintiffs' experience and 
28 
expertise, even as the constitutional standard at issue - whether the police 
 
27 

Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 13   Filed 08/27/14   Page 28 of 34
The Honorable Marsha J. Pechman 
officersโ conduct was objectively reasonable - depends on an examination of the 
1 
specific knowledge, experience, training and circumstances facing those officers.  
2 
Most significantly, Defendants continued even more aggressively to cut Plaintiffs 
3 
out of the process as they raised the most serious of concerns: that the new policy 
4  puts their lives and the lives of citizens in danger. 
5  IV. HARM CAUSED AND RELIEF SOUGHT 
6  75. The dangers and harm cited by Plaintiffs are real, not conjectural.  The 
constitutional right of self-defense includes the right not to be required to take 
7 
unnecessary and therefore unreasonable risks with Plaintiffsโ safety and the safety 
8 
of the public.  The unnecessary and unreasonable risk required by the UF Policy is 
9 
itself the injury.  It is unconstitutional to require Plaintiffs to "gamble with 
10 
their lives."   
11 
76. While the actual UF Policy has only been in place since January 2014, the standards 
12 
reflected in it have been imposed by DOJ since it issued its findings letter on 
13  December 16, 2011, and quickly became the pattern and practice of what has been 
14  required of patrol officers since that time. 
15  77. Plaintiffs seek an immediate injunction against the implementation of SPD's UF 
Policy that went into effect on January 1, 2014, and all related training.  The 
16 
immediacy of this injunction is crucial in light of Plaintiffs' serious and 
17 
significant allegations regarding the unconstitutionality of the UF Policy, and the 
18 
dangers it creates to the safety of SPD patrol officers and the public. Moreover, 
19 
since the intrusion of DOJ in 2011, SPD patrol officers, including new officers at 
20 
the Academy (CJTC), have been improperly trained and conditioned to pause, 
21 
hesitate, overthink and under-react in the face of threats of danger.  The longer 
22  this training/conditioning is ingrained, the harder it will be to undo, and the 
23  safety of officers and the public is further endangered for years, if not decades, 
to come. 
24 
78. Plaintiffs further seek a declaratory judgment that the UF Policy is 
25 
unconstitutional and beyond repair.   Plaintiffs seek a declaration requiring that 
26 
an entirely new UF policy be drafted as soon as possible, but only after obtaining 
27 
substantial input from Plaintiffs and other patrol officers with direct experience 
28 
in appropriate use of force decision-making and tactics in Seattle. 
 
28 

Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 13   Filed 08/27/14   Page 29 of 34
The Honorable Marsha J. Pechman 
79. Plaintiffs seek compensatory damages for lost time and wages, improper disciplinary 
1 
action, or any other personnel actions taken against Plaintiffs for violations of 
2 
the UF Policy where Plaintiffs acted based on their constitutional rights of self-
3 
defense.  Plaintiffs seek punitive damages from Defendants based on Defendants' 
4  callous disregard and belittling of the genuine safety needs of SPD's patrol 
5  officers, as well as Defendants disregard for and rewriting of clearly established 
6  standards regarding use of force and concomitant disregard for the public's and 
Plaintiffs' safety.  Plaintiffs also seek punitive damages for the resources and 
7 
funds redirected away from the safety of patrol officers and the public and wasted 
8 
instead on the production of an unreasonable, unconstitutional UF Policy. 
9 
80. Plaintiffs seek any other relief the court deems appropriate. 
10 
81. Plaintiffs currently represent themselves pro se because of the overwhelming costs 
11 
related to representation in a complex civil rights matter. Plaintiffs seek to 
12 
obtain attorneysโ fees under 42 USC ยง 1988, and hope that due to the availability 
13  of attorneys fees they will be able to obtain in-state counsel to represent them in 
14  this court moving forward. 
15  82. Plaintiffs declare under penalty of perjury that the foregoing is true and correct. 
16 
 
17 
 
Respectfully submitted, 
18 
Dated this August 27, 2014 
 
19

documents.text:
Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 73   Filed 10/17/14   Page 1 of 15
 
 
 
1 
2 
3 
4 
5 
6 
7 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
8 
WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON 
AT SEATTLE 
9 
10  ROBERT MAHONEY et al.,  CASE NO. C14-794 MJP 
11    Plaintiffs,  ORDER ON MOTIONS TO DISMISS 
12    v. 
13  ERIC HOLDER et al., 
14    Defendants. 
 
15 
16  THIS MATTER comes before the Court on Defendant Merrick Bobbโs Motion to 
17  Dismiss on quasi-judicial immunity grounds (Dkt. No. 19) and Defendants City of Seattle, 
18  Mayor Ed Murray, and City Attorney Peter Holmesโs Motion to Dismiss for failure to state a 
19  claim (Dkt. No. 25). Certain represented Plaintiffs responded to the Motions, while the 
20  remaining pro se Plaintiffs failed to respond. Having reviewed the motions, the Represented 
21  Plaintiffsโ Responses (Dkt. Nos. 36, 59), Defendant Bobbโs Reply (Dkt. No. 54), the City 
22  Defendantsโ Reply (Dkt. No. 62), and all related papers, the Court hereby GRANTS both 
23  Motions and DISMISSES the case with prejudice. 
24    
 
ORDER ON MOTIONS TO DISMISS- 1 
 

 
Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 73   Filed 10/17/14   Page 2 of 15
 
 
 
1  Summary 
2    In this case, certain officers with the Seattle Police Department are challenging a Use of 
3  Force Policy adopted in response to an earlier lawsuit filed against the City of Seattle by the 
4  United States Department of Justice. In the earlier lawsuit, the Department of Justice claimed 
5  that the Seattle Police Department engaged in a pattern or practice of excessive use of force. As a 
6  condition of settlement, the City of Seattle agreed to create new policies aimed at preventing this 
7  pattern from repeating. One of the key players in creating the Use of Force Policy was Merrick 
8  Bobb, a โMonitorโ appointed as an agent of the court to assist in the policy-drafting process, 
9  among other tasks. Although many groups gave feedback as the Use of Force Policy was being 
10  developed, individual officers of the Seattle Police Department were not a party to the lawsuit or 
11  the ensuing negotiations. 
12  The officers now argue the new Use of Force Policy violates their constitutional rights by 
13  constraining their options in defending themselves against potentially dangerous suspects. They 
14  also argue that the way the Use of Force Policy was drafted violates the Constitution. They ask 
15  the Court to stop the implementation of the Use of Force Policy, to declare the Use of Force 
16  Policy unconstitutional, and to award them money damages. 
17  As the Court explains in greater detail below, the officersโ constitutional arguments are 
18  not supported by the text of the Constitution or case law interpreting the Constitution. In 
19  addition, the officers cannot sue the court-appointed Monitor Merrick Bobb because he has 
20  โabsolute immunityโ from lawsuits relating to his actions assisting in the resolution of the earlier 
21  lawsuit. This immunity is known as โquasi-judicialโ because it is derived from the immunity 
22  given to judges, and Merrick Bobb is entitled to it both because he was appointed as an agent of 
23 
24 
 
ORDER ON MOTIONS TO DISMISS- 2 
 

 
Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 73   Filed 10/17/14   Page 3 of 15
 
 
 
1  a judge and because he was engaged in activities that parallel those of a judge. Because the 
2  officersโ case is not supported by the Constitution or case law, the Court dismisses the lawsuit. 
3  Background 
4  The Represented Plaintiffs and Plaintiffs representing themselves are police officers 
5  employed by the Seattle Police Department (โSPDโ) who have filed suit to challenge the Use of 
6  Force Policy (โPolicyโ) adopted by the City of Seattle (โCityโ) pursuant to a consent decree and 
7  settlement with the United States Department of Justice (โDOJโ). (Dkt. No. 13 at 3โ4; see Case 
8  No. C12-1282-JLR, United States v. City of Seattle.) In the first lawsuit, the Department of 
9  Justice claimed that after โan extensive investigation of the Seattle Police Department [ . . .], the 
10  United States [ ] determined that SPD engages in patterns or practices of using unlawful force 
11  that systematically deny the people of Seattle their constitutional rights.โ (Case No. C12-1282-
12  JLR, Compl. & DOJ Report, Dkt. No. 1 at 2, cited in Am. Compl., Dkt. No. 13 at 3.) The 
13  settlement agreement and its central components, including the use of force policy it pledged to 
14  produce, had the โgoal of addressing the policies, procedures, training, and oversight that the 
15  United States alleges contributed to a pattern or practice of constitutional violations.โ (See Case 
16  No. C12-1282-JLR, Joint Motion and Proposed Order for Approval of Settlement Agreement, 
17  Dkt. No. 3 at 2โ3, cited in Am. Compl., Dkt. No. 13 at 3โ4; see also Settlement Agreement, 
18  Ryan-Lang Decl., Dkt. No. 12-1 at 17โ18, cited in Am. Compl. Dkt. No. 13 at 3โ4; id., 
19  Memorandum Submitting Use of Force Policy, Dkt. No. 12-2 at 57โ58, cited in Am. Compl., 
20  Dkt. No. 13 at 4.) The agreement included a plan for a court-appointed Monitor. (Dkt. No. 12-1 
21  at 52โ70; Dkt. No. 12-2 at 5โ6.) According to the court-appointed Monitor when he submitted 
22  the Policy to the court, the Policy was โcalibrated to bring about Constitutional policing without 
23 
24 
 
ORDER ON MOTIONS TO DISMISS- 3 
 

 
Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 73   Filed 10/17/14   Page 4 of 15
 
 
 
1  sacrificing the safety and well-being of police officers or the general public.โ (Dkt. No. 12-2 at 
2  58.) 
3  Plaintiffs now allege the Policy is too solicitous of the rights of those being policed and 
4  insufficiently concerned with the rights of those employed as police officers. (See Am. Compl., 
5  Dkt. No. 13 at 2.) Plaintiffs bring their claims under ยง 1983 and Bivens, alleging the creation and 
6  implementation of the Policy violates their own Second and Fourth Amendment rights, their 
7  โright of self-defense as embedded in the Fourth Amendment,โ  the Equal Protection Clause, and 
8  substantive and procedural due process. (Id. at 22โ28.) They seek a declaration that the Policy 
9  infringes on their constitutional rights as well as injunctive relief and damages. (Id. at 28โ29.) 
10    In addition to the City, Mayor Ed Murray, and City Attorney Peter Holmes, Plaintiffs 
11  filed suit against federal actors involved in the settlement agreement and formulation of the 
12  Policy. One of those Defendants is Merrick Bobb, the court-appointed Monitor in the underlying 
13  litigation. Plaintiffs allege that Mr. Bobb is liable for the constitutional errors they identify in the 
14  Policy because he allegedly seized control over the drafting process and refused input from the 
15  Seattle Police Department and its officers. (See Dkt. No. 13 at 5.) 
16    The City Defendants now move to dismiss the Amended Complaint, arguing Plaintiffsโ 
17  allegations fail to state a claim under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6). (Dkt. No. 25.) 
18  Defendant Bobb also moves to dismiss on the grounds of quasi-judicial immunity. (Dkt. No. 19.) 
19  Analysis 
20  I.  Legal Standards 
21  A.  Motion to Dismiss 
22  To survive a motion to dismiss, a complaint must state a claim for relief that is plausible 
23  on its face. Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6); Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 678 (2009). Courts follow a 
24 
 
ORDER ON MOTIONS TO DISMISS- 4 
 

 
Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 73   Filed 10/17/14   Page 5 of 15
 
 
 
1  two-step approach when deciding whether a complaint survives a 12(b)(6) motion. Id. at 678โ79. 
2  First, โa court must accept as true all of the allegations contained in a complaintโ unless the 
3  allegations are legal conclusions. Id. Second, the Court must decide whether the claim for relief 
4  is plausibleโa context-specific task. Id. 
5  B.  Evidence and Related Proceedings at the Motion to Dismiss Stage 
6  Federal Rule of Evidence 201(b) provides that the Court โmay judicially notice a fact that 
7  is not subject to reasonable dispute because it . . . can be accurately and readily determined from 
8  sources whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned.โ Thus, the Court may take notice of 
9  โdocuments [that] are not physically attached to the complaint . . . if the documentsโ โauthenticity 
10  . . . is not contestedโ and โthe plaintiffs complaint necessarily reliesโ on them.โ Lee v. City of Los 
11  Angeles, 250 F.3d 668, 688 (9th Cir. 2001) (citations omitted) (overruled on other grounds by 
12  Galbraith v. County of Santa Clara, 307 F.3d 1119, 1125โ26 (9th Cir. 2002)). The Court may 
13  take judicial notice of โproceedings in other courts, both within and without the federal judicial 
14  system, if those proceedings have a direct relation to matters at issue.โ Bias v. Moynihan, 508 
15  F.3d 1212, 1225 (9th Cir. 2007). However, judicial notice may not extend to disputed facts stated 
16  within public records. Lee, 307 F.3d at 690. 
17  II.  The Monitor and Quasi-Judicial Function 
18  Defendant Bobb argues the claims against him must be dismissed because he has 
19  absolute quasi-judicial immunity from suit in his role as Monitor. (Dkt. No. 19.) โAbsolute 
20  judicial immunity insulates judges from charges of erroneous acts or irregular action.โ Burton v. 
21  Infinity Capital Management, 753 F.3d 954, 959 (9th Cir. 2014) (quotation marks and citations 
22  omitted). It โis not reserved solely for judges, but extends to nonjudicial officers for all claims 
23  relating to the exercise of judicial functions.โ Id. (quotation marks and citations omitted). โThe 
24 
 
ORDER ON MOTIONS TO DISMISS- 5 
 

 
Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 73   Filed 10/17/14   Page 6 of 15
 
 
 
1  proponent of a claim to absolute immunity bears the burden of establishing the justification for 
2  such immunity.โ Antoine v. Byers & Anderson, Inc., 508 U.S. 429, 432 (1993). โTo qualify for 
3  absolute immunity, the function performed must be a judicial act with โa sufficiently close nexus 
4  to the adjudicative process.โ However, โit is only when the judgment of an official other than a 
5  judge involves the exercise of discretionary judgment that judicial immunity may be extended to 
6  that nonjudicial officer.โโ Burton, 753 F.3d at 960 (citations omitted). โTo be protected, the 
7  function performed must โinvolve the exercise of discretion in resolving disputes.โโ Id. Among 
8  the nonjudicial officers that have been extended quasi-judicial immunity are bankruptcy trustees, 
9  id., and court-appointed special masters. Atkinson-Baker & Assocs., Inc. v. Kolts, 7 F.3d 1452, 
10  1455 (9th Cir. 1993). 
11  Plaintiffs acknowledge Mr. Bobb was appointed by the Court in the underlying litigation 
12  to โoversee implementation of the Consent Agreement.โ (Dkt. No. 13 at 4.) According to the 
13  Order Approving Consensus Use of Force Policies, a document cited by Plaintiffs (Dkt. No. 13 
14  at 3), โ[t]he role of the court, and the Monitor who serves as an agent of the court, [was] not to 
15  dictate policies to the SPD, but rather to insure that the Proposed Policies conform to the 
16  requirements of the Consent Decree, the United States Constitution, and judicial decisions 
17  interpreting the Cityโs constitutional obligations.โ (Dkt. No. 12-2 at Ex. 8, p. 65.) Plaintiffs 
18  allege that while Mr. Bobb agreed it was not his role to write the Policy (Dkt. No. 13 at 4, citing 
19  the Memorandum, Dkt. No. 12-2 at Ex. 7), the Policy was โaltered almost in its entirety and 
20  replaced with specific language provided, and required, by the Monitor.โ (Dkt. No. 13 at 5.) 
21  According to Plaintiffs, this โlanguageโ was the outcome preferred by the DOJ as opposed to the 
22  City. (See id. at 5, 27.) The Court must accept for the purpose of this motion that Mr. Bobb 
23  seized control over the drafting process, implemented the DOJโs preferred solutions, and refused 
24 
 
ORDER ON MOTIONS TO DISMISS- 6 
 

 
Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 73   Filed 10/17/14   Page 7 of 15
 
 
 
1  input from other stakeholders such as officers of the Seattle Police Department. The question 
2  remains whether these alleged acts deprived him of quasi-judicial immunity for his role in the 
3  process. 
4  Plaintiffs argue that because the Consent Decree did not grant the Monitor the power to 
5  draft the Policy unilaterally, his actions were not โjudicial.โ (See Dkt. No. 36 at 6.) Plaintiffs 
6  concede โjudicialโ acts have been defined by the Supreme Court to encompass โthe function of 
7  resolving disputes between parties, or of authoritatively adjudicating private rights.โ (Id. at 5, 
8  citing Antoine, 508 U.S. at 435โ36.) It is clear that Mr. Bobb was appointed by the district court 
9  to oversee formulation of a Policy which was both the product and the subject of an ongoing 
10  โdispute between partiesโโnamely, the City of Seattle and the United States Department of 
11  Justice. According to Plaintiffs, Mr. Bobb agreed with the DOJโs preferred solutions and 
12  disagreed with the outcome preferred by Plaintiffs (who were not formal parties to the litigation). 
13  Still, this alleged course of action does not deprive his conduct of judicial character. Far from it: 
14  judges are usually persuaded by one side as opposed to another as they adjudicate disputes in our 
15  adversarial system. An outcome that favors one party is no less a โresolutionโ because it does not 
16  please all stakeholders. Here, the Court agrees with Defendant Bobb that even if Mr. Bobb 
17  engaged in the conduct Plaintiffs assign to him, he was engaged in an essential judicial function: 
18  that of resolving a dispute between the parties to the City of Seattle litigation at the request of a 
19  federal district court judge. 
20  Furthermore, that function involved discretion. See Burton, 753 F.3d at 960. Plaintiffs do 
21  not argue Mr. Bobb was constrained to take a single course of action with respect to the drafting 
22  of the policy, in the manner that a court reporter must produce a verbatim transcript of court 
23  proceedings. Cf. Antoine, 508 U.S. at 436โ37 (holding that court reporters are not entitled to 
24 
 
ORDER ON MOTIONS TO DISMISS- 7 
 

 
Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 73   Filed 10/17/14   Page 8 of 15
 
 
 
1  quasi-judicial immunity because they are afforded no discretion in carrying out their duties). 
2  Rather, Plaintiffs argue that he formulated a policy that contained terms that favored one side in 
3  the dispute (Dkt. No. 36 at 4)โin other words, that he used his court-endowed discretion to 
4  reach a result Plaintiffs do not agree with. 
5  Because Defendant Bobb exercised discretion in resolving a dispute at the request of a 
6  district judge, he is entitled to absolute quasi-judicial immunity from suit and the charges against 
7  him must be dismissed. 
8  III.  Cityโs Substantive Motion to Dismiss 
9  The City Defendants move to dismiss on the basis that Plaintiffsโ allegations fail to state 
10  a claim under the Second or Fourth Amendments, the Equal Protection Clause, or the Due 
11  Process Clause. (Dkt. No. 25.) 
12  A.  Second Amendment 
13  The City Defendants argue the Policy does not violate Plaintiffsโ Second Amendment 
14  rights because while the Second Amendment protects an individualโs right to bear arms, the 
15  Second Amendment does not provide that individuals have a right to use a firearm in any 
16  particular way. (Dkt. No. 25 at 7.) Plaintiffs contend that the Second Amendment codified a 
17  preexisting right to self-defense, and the Policy burdens that right. (Dkt. No. 59 at 4.) 
18  The Ninth Circuit has adopted a two-step test for analysis of Second Amendment claims: 
19  (1) the court asks whether the challenged law burdens conduct protected by the Second 
20  Amendment, and (2) if so, the court determines whether the law meets the appropriate level of 
21  scrutiny. See Jackson v. City & Cnty. of San Francisco, 746 F.3d 953, 960 (9th Cir. 2014); see 
22  also Peruta v. Cnty. of San Diego, 742 F.3d 1144, 1175 (9th Cir. 2014) (declining to apply a 
23  particular level of scrutiny in light of the type of Second Amendment burden imposed). 
24 
 
ORDER ON MOTIONS TO DISMISS- 8 
 

 
Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 73   Filed 10/17/14   Page 9 of 15
 
 
 
1  Plaintiffs can point to no case establishing that the Second Amendment codified a free-
2  standing right to self-defense, as opposed to case law interpreting the textual Second Amendment 
3  rights to โkeep and bear armsโ in light of their purposes (which the Supreme Court has held 
4  include the facilitation of self-defense). See, e.g., District of Columbia v. Heller, 554 U.S. 570, 
5  628 (2008) (โAs the quotations earlier in this opinion demonstrate, the inherent right of self-
6  defense has been central to the Second Amendment right. The handgun ban amounts to a 
7  prohibition of an entire class of โarmsโ that is overwhelmingly chosen by American society for 
8  that lawful purpose.โ). In the criminal context, the Ninth Circuit rejected the idea that recent 
9  Supreme Court cases confirmed a Second Amendment right to use a weapon in any particular 
10  way: โ[N]either [Heller nor McDonald] concerned the use of a weapon, as distinct from mere 
11  possession. . . .โ United States v. Morsette, 622 F.3d 1200, 1202 (9th Cir. 2010). Similarly, 
12  nothing in the Supreme Courtโs recent Second Amendment jurisprudence lends support to 
13  Plaintiffsโ novel theory that a police department policy outlining expectations for an officerโs use 
14  of force can burden conduct protected by the Second Amendment. 
15  Instead, the Supreme Court has been clear that โthe right secured by the Second 
16  Amendment is not unlimitedโ and is โnot a right to keep and carry any weapon whatsoever in 
17  any manner whatsoever and for whatever purpose.โ Heller, 554 U.S. at 626. Plaintiffs selectively 
18  quote historical sources cited in Heller to suggest that so long as self-defense is a purpose for the 
19  individual claiming a Second Amendment right, the Second Amendment forbids โunreasonableโ 
20  restrictions on the manner a weapon is used. (Dkt. No. 59 at 4.) In fact, contemporaneous sources 
21  relied on by the Supreme Court and the Ninth Circuit show that restrictions on the manner in 
22  which a weapon is used fall outside the scope of the Second Amendment. For example, the Ninth 
23  Circuit quoted and the Supreme Court cited the following nineteenth-century footnote: โ[I]t is 
24 
 
ORDER ON MOTIONS TO DISMISS- 9 
 

 
Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 73   Filed 10/17/14   Page 10 of 15
 
 
 
1  generally held that statutes prohibiting the carrying of concealed weapons are not in conflict with 
2  these constitutional provisions, since they merely forbid the carrying of arms in a particular 
3  manner, which is likely to lead to breaches of the peace and provoke to the commission of crime, 
4  rather than contribute to public or personal defence.โ The American Studentsโ Blackstone: 
5  Commentaries on the Laws of England 84 n.11 (George Chase ed., 3d ed. 1890) (emphasis 
6  supplied) (cited in Peruta v. County of San Diego, 742 F.3d 1144, 1165 (9th Cir. 2014) and 
7  District of Columbia v. Heller, 554 U.S. 570, 626 (2008)). Similarly, the Ninth Circuit relied on 
8  nineteenth-century legal commentator John Ordronaux for the proposition that โthe [Second] 
9  Amendment has never prevented โa State from enacting laws regulating the manner in which 
10  arms may be carried.โโ Peruta, 742 F.3d at 1165. According to the Ninth Circuit, these sources 
11  and case law demonstrate that โregulation of the right to bear arms is not only legitimate but 
12  quite appropriate.โ Id. at 1178 (emphasis in original). In addition to the categories of regulation 
13  specifically described in Heller, the Ninth Circuit stated, โNor should anything in this opinion be 
14  taken to cast doubt on the validity of measures designed to make the carrying of firearms for 
15  self-defense as safe as possible, both to the carrier and the community.โ Id. at 1178. 
16  Here, the Policy represents an effort by an employer, the Seattle Police Department, to 
17  regulate the use not only of (employer-issued) weapons but of the force its employees are 
18  specially sanctioned to wield on behalf of the city government. This scenario has no relation to 
19  the Second Amendment guarantees for individuals recognized in Heller, McDonald, and Peruta. 
20  Because the Policy does not burden conduct protected by the Second Amendment, the 
21  Court need not proceed to the second step of the analysis. Plaintiffs fail to state a plausible 
22  Second Amendment claim. 
23 
24 
 
ORDER ON MOTIONS TO DISMISS- 10 
 

 
Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 73   Filed 10/17/14   Page 11 of 15
 
 
 
1  B.  Fourth Amendment 
2  Plaintiffsโ Fourth Amendment argument rests on two grounds: the notion that the Policy 
3  itself effects a metaphorical โseizureโ (Dkt. No. 59 at 9โ11) and the notion that the case law 
4  analyzing the limits of citizensโ Fourth Amendment rights against the government can be flipped 
5  inside out to describe the positive rights of government actors (such as police officers) against 
6  citizens (id. at 11โ12). Both grounds grossly misconstrue Fourth Amendment law. 
7  Fourth Amendment seizures of persons are neither figurative nor hypothetical. The 
8  definition requires that a government actor โby means of physical force or show of authority, 
9  terminates or restrains [a personโs] freedom of movement [ . . . ] through means intentionally 
10  applied.โ Brendlin v. California, 551 U.S. 249, 254 (2007). The Policy does not affect officersโ 
11  freedom of movement, so it does not โseizeโ Plaintiffs, even if, as Plaintiffs allege, the Policy 
12  places them at increased risk of injury. (See Dkt. No. 59 at 9.) 
13  Plaintiffs further argue that cases analyzing the Fourth Amendment rights of citizens have 
14  recognized a โcountervailing governmental interest[ ]โโthus purportedly endowing police 
15  officers with a Fourth Amendment right to use force. (See Dkt. No. 59 at 11, citing Graham v. 
16  Conner, 490 U.S. 386, 396 (1989)). This argument misses the mark entirely. A balancing test 
17  establishing the boundary where government action infringes on a citizenโs Fourth Amendment 
18  rights cannot be reinterpreted as a positive Fourth Amendment right for government actors to 
19  inflict force up to that boundary. 
20  Plaintiffs fail to state a claim under the Fourth Amendment. 
21  C.  Equal Protection Clause 
22  Plaintiffs base their Equal Protection Clause claim on the idea that the Policy burdens 
23  โfundamental rightsโ embedded in the Second and Fourth Amendments. (See Dkt. No. 59 at 12โ
24 
 
ORDER ON MOTIONS TO DISMISS- 11 
 

 
Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 73   Filed 10/17/14   Page 12 of 15
 
 
 
1  13 (citing Tucson Womanโs Clinic v. Eden, 371 F.3d 1173, 1185 (9th Cir. 2004).) The Court has 
2  already analyzed Plaintiffsโ Second and Fourth Amendment arguments and found them wanting. 
3  No Supreme Court case identifies self-defense as a โfundamental rightโ on par with the right to 
4  marry or to vote. 
5  Plaintiffs also fail to make even the most rudimentary showing in an equal protection 
6  claim: they fail to describe themselves as members of an affected class similarly situated to those 
7  outside the class. See City of Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Ctr., 473 U.S. 432, 439 (1985) (โThe 
8  Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment commands that no State shall โdeny to 
9  any person within its jurisdiction the equal protection of the laws,โ which is essentially a 
10  direction that all persons similarly situated should be treated alike.โ). Plaintiffs, like all officers 
11  with the Seattle Police Department, are subject to the Policy; they have identified no group that 
12  is similarly situated yet not subject to the Policy. 
13  Plaintiffs fail to state a claim under the Equal Protection Clause. 
14  D.  Substantive Due Process 
15  Plaintiffs allege substantive due process claims โfor both their rights enumerated in the 
16  Second Amendment, Fourth Amendment, and Equal Protection Clauseโ and โfor their 
17  independent constitutional right to self-defense.โ (Dkt. No. 59 at 13โ14.) As Plaintiffs 
18  acknowledge, substantive due process claims that relate to other constitutional provisions must 
19  be analyzed under the legal standards established for those provisions. See Graham v. Connor, 
20  490 U.S. 386, 394 (1989). As the Court has already explained, Plaintiffs fail to state a claim 
21  under the Second or Fourth Amendment or the Equal Protection Clause. 
22  As for the โindependent constitutional right to self-defense,โ Plaintiffs concede that โno 
23  case has expressly considered whether a police officerโs right to self-defense is protected by the 
24 
 
ORDER ON MOTIONS TO DISMISS- 12 
 

 
Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 73   Filed 10/17/14   Page 13 of 15
 
 
 
1  Constitutionโ but ask the Court to locate it in the penumbrae of other constitutional provisions. 
2  (Dkt. No. 59 at 14โ17.) Courts are โreluctant to expand the concept of substantive due process 
3  because guideposts for responsible decisionmaking in this unchartered area are scarce and open-
4  ended.โ Collins v. City of Harker Heights, 503 U.S. 115, 125 (1992). Executive action such as 
5  the Policy violates substantive due process only when it is arbitrary, that is, when it โshocks the 
6  conscience.โ See County of Sacramento v. Lewis, 523 U.S. 833, 846 (1998). 
7  Plaintiffs characterize the Policy as excessively rigid and complicated. (Dkt. No. 59 at 
8  17.) They assert that delay and injury will result from the Policyโs checks on officersโ responses 
9  to violent suspects. (Id.) But substantive due process does not guarantee a reasonably safe 
10  workplace. Collins, 503 U.S. at 126. It does not shock the conscience to see certain de-escalation 
11  procedures imposed on police officers in an effort by their Department to avoid a pattern or 
12  practice of excessive use of force. (See generally Policy, Case No. C12-1282JLR, Dkt. No. 107 
13  exhibits.) It would be at least surprising if allegations of such a pattern or practice did not lead to 
14  the adoption of stricter standards for use of force by officers. Furthermore, the Policy contains a 
15  number of concessions to the exigencies of the circumstances. (See, e.g., id. at Ex. 1, p. 3 (โAn 
16  Officer Shall Use Only the Degree of Force That Is Objectively Reasonable, Necessary Under 
17  the Circumstances, and Proportional to the Threat or Resistance of a Subject [. . . ] The 
18  reasonableness of a particular use of force is based on the totality of circumstances known by the 
19  officer at the time of the use of force and weighs the actions of the officer against the rights of 
20  the subject, in light of the circumstances surrounding the event. It must be judged from the 
21  perspective of a reasonable officer on the scene, rather than with the 20/20 vision of hindsight[.] 
22  The calculus of reasonableness must embody allowance for the fact that police officers are often 
23  forced to make split-second decisionsโin circumstances that are tense, uncertain, and rapidly 
24 
 
ORDER ON MOTIONS TO DISMISS- 13 
 

 
Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 73   Filed 10/17/14   Page 14 of 15
 
 
 
1  evolvingโabout the amount of force that is necessary in a particular situation.โ).) It must also be 
2  acknowledged that the Policy provides officers with a wide range of tools to gain control over 
3  situations and to protect themselves, from use of verbal commands to physical restraint, 
4  TASERS, pepper spray, and batons, in addition to firearms. (See id. at Ex. 1, pp. 8โ10.) The 
5  Policy is not so inflexible and arbitrary as to shock the conscience, even if it slows or even 
6  forestalls the application of force in police interactions with resisting subjects.  
7  E.  Procedural Due Process 
8  Plaintiffs complain that they were not included in the process by which the Policies were 
9  adopted, but they cite to no case imposing such a requirement on government employers. (See 
10  Dkt. No. 59 at 20.) Furthermore, Plaintiffs locate the liberty interests of which Plaintiffs were 
11  allegedly deprived in the Second and Fourth Amendments, and the Court has already held that 
12  Plaintiffsโ rights in these areas were not violated. (See id.) Plaintiffs were not due any particular 
13  process in the adoption of use-of-force standards by their employer; to the extent they were 
14  invited to participate, that participation was a privilege rather than a right. 
15  F.  Cityโs Other Arguments 
16  The City also argues that Plaintiffs lack standing, fail to state a claim against the Seattle 
17  mayor and city attorney, and do not merit injunctive relief. (Dkt. No. 25 at 20โ23.) Because the 
18  Court concludes Plaintiffs fail to state plausible claims for relief with respect to any defendant, 
19  the Court does not reach these questions. 
20  Conclusion 
21    Because Defendant Bobb is an agent of the court entitled to quasi-judicial immunity, the 
22  Court GRANTS his Motion to Dismiss. (Dkt. No. 19.) In addition, because Plaintiffsโ Complaint 
23  fails to state a claim for relief under ยง 1983 or Bivens for violation of their Second or Fourth 
24 
 
ORDER ON MOTIONS TO DISMISS- 14 
 

 
Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 73   Filed 10/17/14   Page 15 of 15
 
 
 
1  Amendment rights, the Equal Protection Clause, or substantive or procedural due process, the 
2  Court GRANTS the City Defendantsโ Motion to Dismiss. (Dkt. No. 25.) The case is therefore 
3  DISMISSED for failure to state a claim under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6). Because 
4  the Complaint has already been amended once and further amendment would be futile, the 
5  dismissal is with prejudice. 
6   
7  The clerk is ordered to provide copies of this order to all counsel. 
8   
9  Dated this 17th day of October, 2014. 
10   
A
11 
             
 
12 
Marsha J. Pechman 
               
13  Chief United States District Judge
