for the Western District of Washington
Marsha J. Pechman, District Judge, Presiding
Argued and Submitted May 8, 2017
Seattle, Washington
Filed September 19, 2017
Before: Carlos T. Bea and N. Randy Smith, Circuit Judges,
and William Q. Hayes,* District Judge.
Opinion by Judge Hayes
* The Honorable William Q. Hayes, United States District Judge for
the Southern District of California, sitting by designation.

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e5  5o fo 2f 121
MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE 5
SUMMARY**
Second Amendment
The  panel  affirmed  the  district  courtโs  judgment
upholding the use of force policy adopted by the City of
Seattle; and rejected the claims under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 of
plaintiffs,  a  group  of  approximately  125  Seattle  Police
Department (โSPDโ) officers who allege that Seattle violated
the  Second  Amendment  right  of  police  officers  to  use
firearms for the core lawful purpose of self-defense.
The  panel  applied  a  two-step  inquiry  to  determine
whether the challenged law or regulation violated the Second
Amendment. At step one, the panel assumed without deciding
that  the  use  of  force  policy  was  subject  to  Second
Amendment protection.  At step two, the panel held that the
use of force policy recognized that the plaintiffs could use
their  department-issued  firearms  in  self-defense  in  an
encounter with a suspect, and concluded that the use of force
policy did not impose a substantial burden on plaintiffsโ right
to use a firearm for the purpose of lawful self-defense.  The
panel also concluded that the use of force policy was not such
a severe restriction that it amounted to a destruction of the
Second Amendment right.  The panel, therefore, applied the
intermediate level of constitutional scrutiny to determine
whether the policy violated the Second Amendment.
Applying intermediate scrutiny, the panel concluded that
the use of force policy was constitutional under the Second
** This summary constitutes no part of the opinion of the court.  It has
been prepared by court staff for the convenience of the reader.

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e6  6o fo 2f 121
6 MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE
Amendment because there was a reasonable fit between the
policy of Seattleโs important government interest in ensuring
the safety of both the public and its police officers.
The panel also affirmed the district courtโs dismissal of
plaintiffsโ  substantive  due  process  and  equal  protection
claims.
COUNSEL
Athan E. Tramountanas (argued), Short Cressman & Burgess
PLLC, Seattle, Washington; Lisa Ann Battalia, Law Office of
Lisa  Ann  Battalia,  Bethesda,  Maryland;  for  Plaintiffs-
Appellants.
Gregory Colin Narver (argued), Assistant City Attorney;
Peter S.  Holmes, City Attorney; City Attorneyโs  Office,
Seattle, Washington; for Defendants-Appellees.
OPINION
HAYES, District Judge:
We must decide whether the use of force policy adopted
by the City of Seattle violates the Second Amendment right
of police officers to use firearms for the core lawful purpose
of  self-defense.    We  conclude  that  the  policy  survives
intermediate scrutiny and is, therefore, constitutional.  We
affirm the judgment of the district court.

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e7  7o fo 2f 121
MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE 7
FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In 2012, the United States brought a civil action in the
United States  District Court  for the Western District  of
Washington against the City of Seattle, alleging that the
Seattle Police Department (โSPDโ) engaged in a pattern or
practice of excessive use of force.  United States v. City of
Seattle,  Case  No.  2:12-cv-01282-JLR  (W.D.  Wash.). 
Pursuant to a settlement agreement between the parties, the
United States and the City of Seattle worked with a court-
appointed monitor to produce a Use of Force Policy (โUF
Policyโ) that would apply to SPD officersโ use of approved
department firearms while on duty.
On December 17, 2013, United States District Judge
James L. Robart issued an order approving the policy agreed
to  by  the  parties.1    The  UF  Policy2  states,  in  part,  that
โ[o]fficers  shall  only  use  objectively  reasonable  force,
proportional to the threat or urgency of the situation, when
necessary, to achieve a law-enforcement objective.โ  The UF
Policy provides a set of factors that officers must consider to
determine whether a proposed use of force is objectively
reasonable, necessary, and proportional to the threat at issue.
1 The order is styled as an โOrder Approving Consensus Use of Force
Policiesโ submitted by the court-appointed monitor.
2 We take judicial notice of and reference the revised UF Policy in
Appelleesโ request for judicial notice (Dkt. No. 30-2 at 28โ85), as well as
the docket sheet from United States v. City of Seattle, Case No. 12-cv-
01282-JLR (W.D. Wash.).  See Reynโs Pasta Bella, LLC v. Visa USA, Inc.,
442 F.3d 741, 746 n.6 (9th Cir. 2006) (โWe may take judicial notice of
court filings and other matters of public record.โ).  We deny the City of
Seattleโs second request for judicial notice of a subsequent revised UF
Policy on the grounds that the document remains pending court approval.

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e8  8o fo 2f 121
8 MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE
Although the UF Policy requires officers to consider those
factors before using a firearm, the UF Policy also states that
officers must consider those factors only โ[w]hen safe under
the totality of circumstances and time and circumstances
permit[.]โ The UF Policy also requires officers to use de-
escalation tactics to reduce the need for force only โ[w]hen
safe and feasible under the totality of circumstances[.]โ
Appellants, a group of approximately 125 SPD officers,
subsequently brought this action pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983
against the City of Seattle, including SPD and other related
entities, to challenge the constitutionality of the UF Policy. 
Appellants brought claims under the Second, Fourth, Fifth,
and Fourteenth Amendments, alleging that the UF Policy
unreasonably restricts their right to use department-issued
firearms for self-defense.  On October 17, 2014, the district
court granted the motion to dismiss filed by the City of
Seattle, concluding that the UF Policy did not burden conduct
protected by the Second Amendment.  Mahoney v. Holder,
62 F. Supp. 3d 1215, 1222 (W.D. Wash. 2014).  Appellants
timely appealed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
We have jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. ยง 1291.  We review
de novo the district courtโs dismissal for failure to state a
claim under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6).  See
N.M. State Inv. Council v. Ernst & Young LLP, 641 F.3d
1089,  1094  (9th  Cir.  2011).    We  review  de  novo  all
constitutional rulings.  See Wilson v. Lynch, 835 F.3d 1083,
1090 (9th Cir. 2016).  We may affirm on any basis supported
by the record below.  See Bill v. Brewer, 799 F.3d 1295, 1299
(9th Cir. 2015).

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e9  9o fo 2f 121
MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE 9
When evaluating a motion to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(6),
we accept the well-pleaded factual allegations of a complaint
as true and construe all inferences in favor of the nonmoving
party.  Ariz. Studentsโ Assโn v. Ariz. Bd. of Regents, 824 F.3d
858, 864 (9th Cir. 2016).  Dismissal under Rule 12(b)(6) is
warranted if a complaint fails โto state a claim to relief that is
plausible on its face.โ  Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S.
544, 570 (2007).  โConclusory allegations of law . . . are
insufficient to defeat a motion to dismiss.โ  Lee v. City of Los
Angeles, 250 F.3d 668, 679 (9th Cir. 2001).
DISCUSSION
I. Second Amendment Precedent and Two-Step Inquiry
The Second Amendment provides: โA well regulated
Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, the
right of the people to keep and bear Arms, shall not be
infringed.โ  U.S. Const. amend. II.  In District of Columbia v.
Heller,  the  Supreme  Court  concluded  that  District  of
Columbia statutes that required residents to keep firearms in
the home unloaded and disassembled and prohibited the
possession of handguns in the home violated the Second
Amendment.  554 U.S. 570, 574โ75, 635 (2008).  The Court
recognized that โthe inherent right of self-defense has been
central to the Second Amendment right.โ  Id. at 628.  The
Court  concluded  that  the  statutes  at  issue  โma[de]  it
impossible for citizens to use [firearms] for the core lawful
purpose of self-defense and [were] hence unconstitutional.โ 
Id. at 630.  The Court subsequently applied the right to keep
and bear arms for self-defense under the Second Amendment
against the States through the Fourteenth Amendment in
McDonald v. City of Chicago, 561 U.S. 742 (2010).

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e1 01 0o fo 2f 121
10 MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE
Following Heller and McDonald, we โadopt[ed a] two-
step . . . inquiryโ to determine whether a challenged law or
regulation violates the Second Amendment.  United States v.
Chovan, 735 F.3d 1127, 1136 (9th Cir. 2013).  The two-step
inquiry โreflects the Supreme Courtโs holding in Heller that,
while the Second Amendment protects an individual right to
keep and bear arms, the scope of that right is not unlimited.โ 
Id.  A majority of our sister circuits have adopted this two-
step inquiry to analyze Second Amendment claims.  See
Silvester v. Harris, 843 F.3d 816, 820โ21 (9th Cir. 2016).
At the first step, courts ask whether โthe challenged law
burdens conduct protected by the Second Amendment[.]โ 
Chovan, 735 F.3d at 1136.  If a court answers this question in
the  affirmative,  โthe  regulation  is  subject  to  Second
Amendment protection (i.e., the regulation is neither outside
the  historical  scope  of  the  Second  Amendment,  nor
presumptively lawful), [and] the court then proceeds to the
second step of the inquiry to determine the appropriate level
of scrutiny to apply.โ  Silvester, 843 F.3d at 821 (citing
Jackson v. City & Cty. of San Francisco, 746 F.3d 953, 960
(9th Cir. 2014)).
II. Step One: Whether the UF Policy Burdens Conduct
Protected by the Second Amendment
To determine whether the UF Policy burdens conduct
protected by the Second Amendment, we ask whether the UF
Policy  โis  one  of  the  โpresumptively  lawful  regulatory
measuresโ identified in Heller, or whether the record includes
persuasive historical evidence establishing that the regulation
at issue imposes prohibitions that fall outside the historical

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e1 11 1o fo 2f 121
MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE 11
scope of the Second Amendment[.]โ3  Jackson, 746 F.3d at
960 (quoting Heller, 554 U.S. at 627 n.26).
โHeller indicated that the Second Amendment does not
preclude  certain  โlongstanding  prohibitionsโ  and
โpresumptively  lawful  regulatory  measures,โ  such  as
โprohibitions on carrying concealed weapons,โ โprohibitions
on the possession of firearms by felons and the mentally ill,โ
โlaws forbidding the carrying of firearms in sensitive places
such as schools and government buildings,โ โlaws imposing
conditions  and  qualifications  on  the  commercial  sale  of
arms,โ and prohibitions on โthe carrying of โdangerous and
unusual weapons,โโ referring to weapons that were not โin
common use at the timeโ of the enactment of the Second
Amendment.โ  Id. at 959 (quoting Heller, 554 U.S. at 626โ27,
627 n.26).  In this case, the UF Policyโan employer policy
that regulates a police officerโs use of a department-issued
firearm  while  on  dutyโdoes  not  resemble  any  of  the
โpresumptively lawfulโ regulations  recognized in  Heller. 
554 U.S. at 627 n.26.
Next, we examine the record to determine โwhether there
is persuasive historical evidence showing that the regulation
does not impinge on the Second Amendment right as it was
historically understood.โ  Silvester, 843 F.3d at 821.  In this
case, the parties have not provided any โpersuasive historical
evidenceโ demonstrating that regulating police officersโ use
3 Appellants assert that the UF Policy infringes on their Second
Amendment right to self-defense and then frame the historical inquiry
around this right.  The scope of Appellantsโ inquiry is too broad.  Instead,
we must examine whether restrictions on a government employeeโs use of
a government-issued firearm in the line of duty fall outside the historical
scope of the Second Amendment.

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e1 21 2o fo 2f 121
12 MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE
of department-issued firearms is historically longstanding or
falls outside the historical scope of the Second Amendment. 
Jackson, 746 F.3d at 960, 963.  We do not purport to rule
definitively  on  whether,  historically,  officers  have  been
restricted in the use of their government-issued firearms
while acting within the scope of their employment.  However,
โ[b]ecause of the lack of historical evidence in the record
before us,โ see Chovan, 735 F.3d at 1137 (internal quotation
mark and citation omitted), โwe assume, without deciding,
that the [UF Policy] burdens conduct falling within the scope
of the Second Amendment.โ  Bauer v. Becerra, 858 F.3d
1216, 1221 (9th Cir. 2017).
Because  the  UF  Policy  resembles  none  of  the
presumptively lawful measures identified in Heller, and the
parties have adduced no evidence that the UF Policy imposes
a restriction on conduct that falls outside the historical scope
of the Second Amendment right to use a firearm for self-
defense, we assume the UF Policy โis subject to Second
Amendment protectionโ and we proceed to the second step of
the inquiry.4  Silvester, 843 F.3d at 821.
III. Step Two: Applying Constitutional Scrutiny to the
UF Policy
A. Determining the Level of Scrutiny
To ascertain the proper level of constitutional scrutiny to
apply to the UF Policy at the second step, we must consider:
4 The district court concluded that the UF Policy did not burden
conduct protected by the Second Amendment, and therefore did not
proceed to the second step of the inquiry.  See Mahoney, 62 F. Supp. 3d
at 1221โ22.

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e1 31 3o fo 2f 121
MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE 13
โ(1) how close the challenged law comes to the core of the
Second Amendment right, and (2) the severity of the lawโs
burden on that right.โ  Silvester, 843 F.3d at 821 (citing
Jackson, 746 F.3d at 960โ61).  A restriction โthat implicates
the  core  of  the  Second  Amendment  right  and  severely
burdens  that  right  warrants  strict  scrutiny[,]โ  while  a
restriction  that  โโdoes  not  implicate  a  core  Second
Amendment right, or does not place a substantial burden on
the  Second  Amendment  rightโโ  warrants  intermediate
scrutiny.  Id. (quoting Jackson, 746 F.3d at 961).
In addressing the extent to which the UF Policy burdens
Appellantsโ  constitutional  right  under  the  Second
Amendment, we begin with Hellerโs holding that the Second
Amendment protects the right of citizens to use a firearm โfor
the core lawful purpose of self-defense[.]โ  Heller, 554 U.S.
at  630.    When  evaluating  the  constitutional  claim  of  a
government employee, however, the Supreme Court instructs
us to balance the rights of the employee โagainst the realities
of the employment context.โ  Engquist v. Or. Depโt of Agr.,
553 U.S. 591, 600 (2008).
In Engquist, the Supreme Court affirmed the dismissal of
an equal protection challenge to the decision of the Oregon
Department of Agriculture to terminate an employee โin a
seemingly arbitrary or irrational manner.โ  Id. at 605.  The
Court stated, โWe have long held the view that there is a
crucial difference, with respect to constitutional analysis,
between the government exercising โthe power to regulate or
license,  as  lawmaker,โ  and  the  government  acting  โas
proprietor, to manage [its] internal operation.โโ  Id. at 598
(quoting  Cafeteria  &  Rest.  Workers  Union  v.  McElroy,
367 U.S. 886, 896 (1961)).  โ[I]n striking the appropriate
balance, we consider whether the asserted employee right

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e1 41 4o fo 2f 121
14 MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE
implicates the basic concerns of the relevant constitutional
provision, or whether the claimed right can more readily give
way to the requirements of the government as employer.โ  Id.
at 600.  The Court concluded that the โgovernmentโs interest
in achieving its goals as effectively and efficiently as possible
is elevated from a relatively subordinate interest when it acts
as sovereign to a significant one when it acts as employer.โ 
Id. at 598โ99 (quoting Waters v. Churchill, 511 U.S. 661, 675
(1994)  (plurality  opinion));  see  also  Nordyke  v.  King,
681  F.3d  1041,  1044โ45  (9th  Cir.  2012)  (en  banc)
(concluding that an ordinance regulating โthe sale of firearms
. . . only minimally, and only on County propertyโ was
constitutional under the Second Amendment, while citing
with approval the Engquist lawmaker/proprietor distinction);
Bonidy v. U.S. Postal Serv., 790 F.3d 1121, 1126โ27 (10th
Cir.  2015)  (concluding  that  a  regulation  prohibiting  the
possession  of  firearms  on  Postal  Service  property  was
constitutional under the Second Amendment, recognizing that
โ[t]he government often has more flexibility to regulate when
it is acting as a proprietor (such as when it manages a post
office) than when it is acting as a sovereign (such as when it
regulates  private  activity  unconnected  to  a  government
service)โ).
In this case, the UF Policy regulates Appellantsโ use of
department-issued firearms while acting in the course and
scope of their official duties as police officers.  The firearms
regulated by the UF Policy are issued to Appellants by the
City of Seattle in its capacity as proprietor.  The UF Policy
was adopted by the City of Seattle as an employer to regulate
the conduct of its police officers.  Because the City of Seattle
has a significant interest in regulating the use of department-
issued  firearms  by  its  employees,  we  conclude  that  the
application  of  intermediate  scrutiny  to  the  UF  Policy

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e1 51 5o fo 2f 121
MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE 15
appropriately places the burden on the City of Seattle to
justify placing restrictions on any Second Amendment right
of its employees, while also giving the City the flexibility to
act as an employer.
The  second  factor  in  determining  what  level  of
constitutional scrutiny to apply to the UF Policy requires us
to consider the severity of the UF Policyโs burden on the right
of citizens to use a firearm for the core lawful purpose of self-
defense.  See Chovan, 735 F.3d at 1138.  โThis court has
explained that laws which regulate only the โmanner in which
persons may exercise their Second Amendment rightsโ are
less burdensome than those which bar firearm possession
completely.โ  Silvester, 843 F.3d at 827 (quoting Chovan,
735 F.3d at 1138).  However, to determine the severity of the
burden on the Second Amendment right, we look closely at
the restriction on the manner of firearm possession to ensure
it is not โsuch a severe restriction on the core right of self-
defense that it โamounts to a destruction of the [Second
Amendment] right[.]โโ  Jackson, 746 F.3d at 961 (quoting
Heller, 554 U.S. at 629); see also Peruta v. Cty. of San Diego,
824 F.3d 919, 950 (9th Cir. 2016) (en banc) (Callahan, J.,
dissenting)  (courts  should  consider  Second  Amendment
challenges to firearm restrictions in โcontextโ to ensure the
restrictions are not โtantamount to complete bans on the
Second Amendment right to bear arms outside the home for
self-defenseโ), cert. denied, โ U.S. โ, 137 S. Ct. 1995 (June
26, 2017).
In this case, the UF Policy applies to Appellantsโ use of
department-issued firearms in the course and scope of their
official duties.  The UF Policy states that a police officer
โmay draw or exhibit a firearm in the line of duty when the
officer has reasonable cause to believe it may be necessary

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e1 61 6o fo 2f 121
16 MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE
for his or her own safety or for the safety of others[.]โ  The
UF Policy states that prior to using physical force during an
incident with a subject, Appellants โshall consider whether a
subjectโs lack of compliance is a deliberate attempt to resist
or an inability to comply based onโ a variety of factors,
including the subjectโs possible medical conditions, mental
impairment, developmental disability, drug interaction, and
behavioral crisis.  The UF Policy requires that โwhen safe
under  the  totality  of  the  circumstances  and  time  and
circumstances permit, officers shall use de-escalation tactics
in order to reduce the need for force[.]โ
The UF Policy explicitly recognizes that Appellants may
use their department-issued firearms in self-defense in an
encounter with a suspectโincluding the use of deadly force
with a firearm.  The UF Policy states that โ[d]eadly force may
only be used in circumstances where threat of death or serious
physical injury to the officer or others is imminent[,]โ and
recognizes  that  โsometimes  the  use-of-force  is
unavoidable[.]โ  As a result, the UF Policy does not impose
a substantial burden on Appellantsโ right to use a firearm for
the purpose of lawful self-defense.  See Jackson, 746 F.3d at
968 (concluding that a statute prohibiting the sale of hollow-
point bullets did not โplace a substantial burden on the
Second Amendment rightโ because the statute โlimits only
the  manner  in  which  a  person  may  exercise  Second
Amendment rights by making it more difficult to purchase
certain types of ammunition.โ).  Thus, the nature of the
burden imposed by the UF Policy on Appellantsโ Second
Amendment right to use a firearm for the lawful purpose of
self-defense favors the application of intermediate scrutiny.
Accordingly, we conclude that the UF Policy does not
impose a substantial burden on the Second Amendment right

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e1 71 7o fo 2f 121
MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE 17
to use a firearm for the core lawful purpose of self-defense. 
We also conclude that the UF Policy is not โsuch a severe
restriction on the core right of self-defense that it โamounts to
a destruction of the [Second Amendment] right[.]โโ  Jackson,
746 F.3d at 961 (quoting Heller, 554 U.S. at 629). Therefore,
we apply intermediate scrutiny to determine whether the UF
Policy  violates  the  Second  Amendment.    See  Silvester,
843 F.3d at 823 (โThere is accordingly near unanimity in the
post-Heller case law that when considering regulations that
fall within the scope of the Second Amendment, intermediate
scrutiny is appropriate.โ).
B. Application of Intermediate Scrutiny
โIn  the  context  of  Second  Amendment  challenges,
intermediate scrutiny requires: โ(1) the governmentโs stated
objective to be significant, substantial, or important; and (2) a
reasonable fit between the challenged regulation and the
asserted objective.โโ  Fyock v. Sunnyvale, 779 F.3d 991, 1000
(9th Cir. 2015) (quoting Chovan, 735 F.3d at 1139).
At  the  first  step,  in  order  to  determine  whether  the
governmentโs interest is significant, substantial, or important,
we  first  define  the  governmentโs  objective.    Jackson,
746  F.3d  at  965.    In  Jackson,  we  explained  that  โ[i]n
considering a cityโs justifications for its ordinance, we do not
impose โan unnecessarily rigid burden of proof . . . so long as
whatever evidence the city relies upon is reasonably believed
to be relevant to the problem that the city addresses.โโ  Id.
(quoting City of Renton v. Playtime Theatres, Inc., 475 U.S.
41, 50โ52 (1986)).
In this case, the joint findings of fact and conclusions of
law approved by the district judge in the United States v. City

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e1 81 8o fo 2f 121
18 MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE
of Seattle litigation states that the City of Seattleโs goal in
joining the settlement agreement was to โensure[] that SPDโs
policies [and] procedures . . . are sufficient to prevent . . . a
pattern or practice of constitutional violations.โ  The section
of  the  UF  Policy  titled  โCore  Principlesโ  states  that
Appellants must โuse only the force necessary to perform
their duties[,]โ and explains that โ[a]n officerโs commitment
to public safety includes the welfare of members of the
public, the officer, and fellow officers[.]โ
The City of Seattle has the important government interest
of ensuring the safety of both  the public and its  police
officers.  See United States v. Salerno, 481 U.S. 739, 748
(1987)  (โ[T]he  Governmentโs  regulatory  interest  in
community  safety  can,  in  appropriate  circumstances,
outweigh an individualโs liberty interest.โ); Jackson, 746 F.3d
at 965 (quoting Chovan, 735 F.3d at 1139) (โโIt is self-
evident,โ . . . that public safety is an important government
interest.โ).  The record establishes that the City of Seattle
enacted the UF Policy to address the important government
objective of ensuring public safety and police officer safety. 
See Chovan, 735 F.3d at 1140 (โWe hold that the government
has met its burden to show that reducing domestic gun
violence is an important government objective.โ).
At  the  second  step,  we  consider  whether  there  is  a
reasonable fit between the UF Policy and the City of Seattleโs
asserted objective of ensuring the safety of the public and its
police officers.  In determining the degree of fit between the
challenged regulation and its asserted objective, the City of
Seattle is โnot required to show that [the UF Policy] is the
least restrictive means of achieving its interest.โ  Fyock,
779 F.3d at 1000 (citing Jackson, 746 F.3d at 966).  To
survive intermediate scrutiny, we must determine whether the

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e1 91 9o fo 2f 121
MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE 19
record shows that the UF Policy โpromotes a โsubstantial
government interest that would be achieved less effectively
absent the regulation.โโ  Id. (quoting Colacurcio v. City of
Kent, 163 F.3d 545, 553 (9th Cir. 1998)).
In this case, the UF Policy states that โ[o]fficers shall only
use objectively reasonable force, proportional to the threat or
urgency of the situation, when necessary, to achieve a law-
enforcement objective.โ  The UF Policy also requires that
Appellants use โ[d]e-escalation tactics and techniques . . .
when  safe  and  without  compromising  law  enforcement
priorities,โ and states that Appellants โshall consider whether
a subjectโs lack of compliance is a deliberate attempt to resist
or an inability to comply based onโ a variety of factors. 
Those provisions advance the City of Seattleโs important
government interest of ensuring the safety of the public by
mandating  de-escalation  techniques  and  reducing  the
likelihood that a firearm will be drawn or used where such
force is not โobjectively reasonable,โ โproportional to the
threat or urgency of the situation,โ or โnecessary to achieve
a law-enforcement objective.โ
The  UF  Policy  also  advances  the  City  of  Seattleโs
important government interest of ensuring the safety of its
police officers. The UF Policy requires Appellants to employ
de-escalation techniques only โ[w]hen safe under the totality
of the circumstances and time and circumstances permit.โ
Thus, the UF Policy expressly contemplates that de-escalation
techniques will not be feasible in every situation, and even
states that โsometimes, the use of force is unavoidable.โ The
UF Policy also provides that Appellants may use deadly force
where an objectively reasonable officer would conclude that
the โthreat of death or serious physical injury to the officer or
others is imminent.โ These provisions ensure that Appellants

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e2 02 0o fo 2f 121
20 MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE
may  use  their  department-issued  firearms  to  defend
themselves and the public.
In adopting the UF Policy, the City of Seattle drew
โreasonable inference[s]โ that the UF Policy would assist in
ensuring the safety of both the public and its police officers. 
Jackson, 746 F.3d at 966.  The UF Policy advances an
important government interest that would be achieved less
effectively in its absence.  See Silvester, 843 F.3d at 829
(concluding that a statute imposing a ten-day waiting period
to purchase firearms on certain individuals was reasonably fit
to stateโs public safety objective).  Given the City of Seattleโs
important interest in promoting the safety of the public and its
police officers, we determine there is a reasonable fit between
the UF Policy and this significant goal.  We conclude that the
UF Policy survives intermediate scrutiny and is, therefore,
constitutional under the Second Amendment.  Because we
find the UF Policy is constitutional, we affirm the district
courtโs dismissal of the Second Amendment claim.
IV. The Substantive Due Process and Equal Protection
Claims
We  also  affirm  the  district  courtโs  dismissal  of  the
remaining claims.  First, we agree with the district court that
current  case  law  does  not  support  the  existence  of  a
freestanding fundamental right to self-defense outside of the
โthe right of law-abiding, responsible citizens to use arms in
defense of hearth and home.โ  Heller, 554 U.S. at 635. 
Because  precedent  does  not  support  recognizing  the
fundamental right Appellantsโ assert, Appellantsโ substantive
due process claim is not a cognizable claim upon which relief
can be granted.

  CCaassee:  21:41-43-5cv9-7000,7 0994/-1M9/J2P0 1  7D,o IcDu: m10e5n8t 57593  2 F, iDlekdt E0n9t/r1y9: /5107-  1 P, Pagaeg e2 12 1o fo 2f 121
MAHONEY V. CITY OF SEATTLE 21
Second,  the  district  court  properly  concluded  that
Appellants failed to state a cognizable equal protection claim. 
Appellants failed to allege facts to support the claim that they
are  being  denied  a  fundamental  right  while  others  are
permitted to exercise such right, and that there is no valid
justification for the distinction.  Further, this claim is not
cognizable under the Equal Protection Clause because it is
โno more than a [Second] Amendment claim dressed in equal
protection clothing[.]โ  Orin v. Barclay, 272 F.3d 1207, 1213
n.3 (9th Cir. 2001).
CONCLUSION
The City of Seattle has a significant interest in regulating
the use of department-issued firearms by its police officers,
and the UF Policy does not impose a substantial burden on
the Second Amendment right to use a firearm for the core
lawful  purpose  of  self-defense.    Therefore,  we  apply
intermediate scrutiny to determine whether the UF Policy
violates the Second Amendment right of its police officers. 
We conclude that the UF Policy is constitutional under the
Second Amendment because there is a reasonable fit between
the UF Policy and the City of Seattleโs important government
interest in ensuring the safety of both the public and its police
officers.    We  affirm  the  district  courtโs  dismissal  of
Appellantsโ Second Amendment claim.
We affirm the ruling of the district court on all other
grounds.
AFFIRMED.

V. CONSTITUTIONAL CLAIMS 
1 
A.  Plaintiffs Have the Right to Self-Defense and Defense of Others Under the Second 
and Fourth Amendments and These Rights are Violated by the UF Policy. 
2 
3  1.  When a police officer is confronted with threatening behavior, he or she has the fundamental, 
4 
individual right of self-defense under the Second Amendment, consistent with every other 
5 
citizen, to protect himself or herself, and others, from apparent and immediate harm. As the 
6 
Court has long recognized, the rules that define and determine self-defense are of universal 
7 
8  application and are not affected by the character of a person's employment. Indeed, where 
9  employees have a duty to protect others, their right to defend themselves and others is arguably 
10 
enhanced. In many ways, these rights closely overlap patrol officers' rights to use force under the 
11 
Fourth Amendment, especially when defending themselves against suspects who pose an 
12 
immediate threat to their safety or the safety of others. 
13 
14  2.  However, distinct from the Fourth Amendment standard of'objective reasonableness' is a long 
15  tradition of self-defense law that establishes a 'reasonable belief standard. As such, there need 
16 
only be 'reasonable grounds' for a person's belief that he or she is in imminent or immediate 
17 
danger at the time of the acts in self-defense or defense of others.  Like objective reasonableness, 
18 
the reasonable belief standard does not rest on the 'actual facts' of the situation, but rather on the 
19 
20  'apparent danger' perceived by the individual acting in defense of self or others.  Moreover, 
21 
under the Second Amendment, the more serious the apparent danger perceived at the moment of 
22 
self-defense or defense of others, the less detached or 'objective' the test of reasonableness has to 
23 
be. 
24 
3.  As discussed in detail in section VI.A below, the UF Policy, particularly the deadly force 
25 
26  provision, violates Plaintiffs' rights and protections secured by theses standards under the

B.  Police Officers have Constitutional Protections under the Fourth Amendment, 
Distinct from the Interests of the Government, and/or the Rights of the Citizens and 
8 
These Protections are Unreasonably Burdened by the UF Policy.

1.  The Supreme Court's Fourth Amendment jurisprudence -the core legal parameters that guide 
10 
police interactions with persons engaged, or suspected of engagement, in criminal activity -
11 
12  contains clear and longstanding standards and principles regarding seizures by police officers. 
13 
In fact, force is itself a seizure, and therefore subject to the same requirements for reasonable 
14 
suspicion and probable cause as all other seizures.  The Fourth Amendment balances three 
15 
distinct sets of interests when considering the reasonableness of an officer's decision to make a 
16 
seizure:  (1) the private citizen's interests against unreasonable intrusion by the government; (2) 
17 
18  the government's interest in detecting, investigating, and preventing crime; and (3) the "more 
19 
immediate interest of the police officer" in protecting himself or herself and others from danger, 
20 
because it is unreasonable to require that police officers take unnecessary risks in the 
21 
performance of their duties.  Thus, the Fourth Amendment gives patrol officers distinct 
22 
constitutional protection against being required to take unnecessary risks with their lives and 
23 
24  safety.

1.  DOJ, the City and SPD leadership are under the mistaken belief that they can unreasonably 
23 
restrict and burden, and subsequently punish Plaintiffs, for using reasonable force allowed by the 
24 
Second and Fourth Amendments, in a confrontation between the police and suspects.  Plaintiffs'

26 
SPD Officers'ยง 1983 Complaint  17 

Case 2:14-cv-00794-MJP   Document 1   Filed 05/28/14   Page 18 of 80
incorporated, and apply to the States and municipalities, such as the City and SPD, under the 
Fourteenth Amendment. As applies against all Defendants, the Court holds that public 
employees do not lose Fourth Amendment rights when they work for the government.  Nor are 
they relegated to watered-down versions of constitutional protections.  Moreover, the Court 
specifically holds that constitutional protections against unreasonable search or seizures do not 
disappear because the government employer has the right to make reasonable intrusions or 
impositions. 
Here Plaintiffs are granted protection under the Second and Fourth Amendments not to be 
required to take unreasonable risk with their safety.  It is the unreasonable risk itself that is the 
constitutional injury, and it is the policy and practices demanded by DOJ and implemented by

b. The UF Policy Applies Segmented and Deconstructive Rules to Officers' 
Judgments in Violation of the Fourth (and Second) Amendments.

1.  The UF Policy violates the protections granted patrol offers under the Fourth Amendment by

3  requiring both analysis ofthe officer's prior conduct, and a post-hoc, point-by-point critique

9  subsequent use of force was necessary (again ignoring that the constitutional test is 
10 
"reasonableness").  This expressly contradicts the Ninth Circuit and other circuits holding

and officers need to be armed and ready, because they are always behind the reactionary

curve of a potential suspect who has decided to shoot, stab, slash, or smash as a means of

21  resistance or escape.  The fact that the officer displaying his gun may have caused a suspect 
22 
to respond by pulling out his gun is absolutely irrelevant to what happens next.  Just like any

respond to that threat with deadly force.  The new UF Policy creates questions and

5 
the Test of Reasonableness. 
6 
1.  Fourth Amendment case law is quite clear.  The test of reasonableness is not capable of

10

15  requirement, notwithstanding that the Court has specifically rejected just such rigid rule(s). 
16 
In these circumstances, as in all cases of force, the officer's conduct must be evaluated based 
17 
on one flexible standard: was it objectively reasonable in light of the circumstances as they 
18 
appeared to the officer at the time of the incident? Any other mechanical test undermines the 
19 
protections granted police officers not to take unnecessary and therefore unreasonable risks

21  with their safety or the safety of others.
